content.description: An astronaut with a mass of <math alttext="100 kilograms" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>100</mn><mtext> kg</mtext></math> stands on a scale inside a spaceship. The scale measures a force of <math alttext="2000 newtons" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2000</mn><mtext> N</mtext></math>. Two students make the following claims.
content.question: Claim <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>A</mtext></math>: The spaceship is sitting on the surface of a planet, at rest, where the gravitational acceleration is <math alttext="20 meters per second squared" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>20</mn><mtext> </mtext><msup><mrow><mtext>m</mtext><mo>/</mo><mtext>s</mtext></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup></math>. Claim <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>B</mtext></math>: The spaceship is far from any planet or star and accelerating upward with an acceleration of <math alttext="20 meters per second squared" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>20</mn><mtext> </mtext><msup><mrow><mtext>m</mtext><mo>/</mo><mtext>s</mtext></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup></math>. Based only on observing the scale reading, which of the following is the most accurate?

choices.label: Claim <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>A</mtext></math> must be true, but not Claim <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>B</mtext></math>.
Claim <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>B</mtext></math> must be true, but not Claim <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>A</mtext></math>.
One of the two claims must be true, but it cannot be determined which from the scale reading alone.

skill.text: 3.B: Apply an appropriate law, definition, theoretical relationship, or model to make a claim.
